qas.question: Where do many non-transparent translation theories delve for concepts?
When did Schleiermacher publish his lecture "On the Different Methods of Translation"?
Moving the writer toward the reader would be an example of what type of translation method?
What method of translation did Schleiermacher favor?

answers.text: extreme fidelity to the foreignness of the source text

qas.question: Where do no non-transparent translation theories delve for concepts?
What nationality was Friedrich Schleiermacher afraid of?
When did Schleiermacher erase his lecture "On the Different Methods of Translation"?
What type of translation method would moving the writer away from the reader be an example of?

plausible_answers.text: extreme fidelity to the foreignness of the source text

qas.question: What method of translation did Schleiermacher dislike?

context: Many non-transparent-translation theories draw on concepts from <a0_0><b5_0>German Romanticism<b5_0/><a0_0/>, the most obvious influence being the <a1_0><b6_0>German<b6_0/><a1_0/> theologian and philosopher Friedrich Schleiermacher. In his seminal lecture "On the Different Methods of Translation" (<a2_0><b7_0>1813<b7_0/><a2_0/>) he distinguished between translation methods that move "the writer toward [the reader]", i.e., <a3_0><b8_0>transparency<b8_0/><a3_0/>, and those that move the "reader toward [the author]", i.e., an <a4_0><b9_0>extreme fidelity to the foreignness of the source text<b9_0/><a4_0/>. Schleiermacher favored the latter approach; he was motivated, however, not so much by a desire to embrace the foreign, as by a nationalist desire to oppose France's cultural domination and to promote German literature.
